Comment: > She listed a home answer having 4 rooms on a si gle document, when on other documents, she correctly listed it as 5.  I think you've got that backwards. It's a multi-family residence that a single 2001 document says has 5 units, but various documents she's filed for mortgage and insurance purposes lists it as only 4 units. The government alleges she's been lying about it only having 4 units because it allowed her to get a more favorable loan and cheaper insurance.

Comment: > Crucially, this is rarely, if ever, done by the FBI.  So why did it take 5 seconds of searching to find this if it literally never happens?  > “Mortgage fraud ruins lives, destroys families, and devastates whole communities,” Attorney General Eric Holder said this morning at a press conference to announce the results of “Operation Stolen Dreams.” Launched on March 1, 2010, the multi-agency initiative has led to a total of 485 arrests. More than 330 convictions have been obtained, and nearly $11 million has been recovered. Losses from a variety of fraud schemes are estimated to exceed $2 billion.  > Operation Stolen Dreams is the government’s largest mortgage fraud takedown to date. But FBI Director Robert S. Mueller cautioned that there is still much work to be done. **The Bureau is currently pursuing more than 3,000 mortgage fraud cases**, he said, which is almost double the number from the last fiscal year.  > https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/news/stories/2010/june/mortgage-fraud-sweep
Author: Moccus

Comment: These were for organized mortgage fraud performed at scale and with intent after the 2008 mortgage crisis.  The DOJ does _not_ investigate someone writing a different number on a forms. Case in point: when Trump was convicted of fraud, it was James' department investigating him, not the DOJ.  The only people who keep doing this are Republicans who are weaponizing the DOJ.
